fields.description: You can embed one table in a list, but not two.
fields.summary: Table and List Syntax Don't Co-Operate

fields.description:
This has occurred to several users at the same site, see http://support.atlassian.com/browse/CSP-1158 and http://support.atlassian.com/browse/CSP-1156.

It occurs when submitting an edited page, and Confluence becomes unresponsive until it is restarted.
fields.summary: Unique constraint violated during page update

fields.description:
Create a page
Add an attachment to the page, with some comment text
Search for the comment text. It is found.
Edit the page.
Wait for the page to be indexed
Search for the comment text. It is no longer found.
Rebuild the index.
Search for the comment text. It is found again.
fields.summary: Indexing a page removes the indexes for the comments on attachments belonging to the page

fields.description: It would be nice if you could copy and paste from the markup of comments while incorporating their ideas into the body of a page.
fields.summary: Allow viewing of wiki markup of comments, to assist page refactoring

fields.description:
You just get a blank page rather than the configured custom 404 error page under Websphere.

The "This page may have moved" 404 page displays correctly.
fields.summary: 404 page does not display under Websphere

fields.description:
Hi,
we've been running 1.4-DR6 Build:#203 for a while, and have been having regular crashes. We've tried to upgrade, but the process repeatedly bombs, and suspect that this is something to do with corruption in our HSQL database.
We'd like to move over to the current 1.4.1 version, using MySQL (hopefully MySQL- but if we have to use another DB we're open to that) running on a separate Linux machine.

My questions:
1) does the diagnosis of some kind of corruption in the db make sense- have other people had this problem of frequent (every 1-3d) crashes? Or is it likely to be something else?
2) what is the best approach for this kind of installation-  install over the top, or to create a new instance and then transfer data?
3) is there any way to bring data over from HSQL in to MySQL? (apart from spending a long night copying and pasting pages manually)

thanks

Ben
fields.summary: Upgrading from 1.4 DR6 with HSQL to 1.4.1 MySQL

fields.description: See http://support.atlassian.com/browse/CSP-1160
fields.summary: Javascript error in IE when clicking on non-existant page link

fields.description:
I have a macro plugin that can pull content from an external source (ex a database). I'd like to encorporate this into the builtin search. The only way I see to extend the search is through static means. 

If I have to, I could try to intercept the search by using a different template and a new xwork search plugin, but it would be nice to see this integrated by default.

Also, it would be nice to see a full fledged search grammar like windows desktop search, and then I could extend that also with my plugin.
fields.summary: Search Plugin Datasources

fields.description:
Essentially, what we need is a set of  "routines"  to be exposed so we can use an external interface to execute these services.

Examples:
User[ ] browseUsers(String token, boolean viewAll) --- get all default confluence-users if viewAll == false ; get all registered users if viewAll == true (effectively getActiveUsers() and getAllUsers())
boolean deactivateUser(String token, String username) -- deactivate a user
boolean reactivateUser(Strign token, String username) - reactivate a user

How can we access the above routines (and others if available) from outside of Confluence? (e.g., via SOAP calls)

Thanks
fields.summary: Add getActiveUsers(), deactivate/activateUser() remote API methods

fields.description: Under some unknown circumstances it's possible to get illegal characters (e.g. Unicode 0xffff) in the CDATA sections of entities.xml. We should filter the data as we are creating the backups, and handle the problem when importing.
fields.summary: Filter Illegal characters from CDATA sections when creating backups

fields.description:
When people make themselves a watcher of a page they don't get e-mail notifications when the page is modified.

Checking the mail queue shows that there are numerous errors (com.atlassian.mail.MailException) - resending them only results in them getting put back in the error queue.

The server logs do not provide additional details as to why the mail is not getting through.
fields.summary: THe Mail Queues Error Queue gets Filled with Mail Exceptions

fields.description: After creating a User Macro, I edit it and uncheck the "Macro has a body" checkbox. Then I re-edit the macro and the checkbox is still checked.
fields.summary: Cannot un-check "Macro has a body" flag
Breadcrumbs ">" are partly hardcoded...

fields.description:
Links like this do not render correctly:

[Link|file://G:\work\docs\Quote.doc]

Was working ok in 1.2.1
fields.summary: Shortcut links not working in this release

Brendan

fields.description:
Confluence should be able to act as a WebDav server:

User logs on via WebDav to the Confluence server, or maybe to an individual Confluence space. Confluence itself then becomes a virtual filesystem. Pages are represented as a hierarchy of directories that match the page heirarchy. Each directory contains a text file containing the page's wiki-text, a file for each attachment on the page, and a directory for each child-page.

News is stored in /SPACEKEY/@news/yyyy/mm/dd/News Title/
User profiles are stored in /@users/username/

Editing a page's wiki-text file edits the page. Editing a file edits the attachment. Creating a new directory creates a new page. Etc.

(Can this be done entirely as a plugin?)
fields.summary: Confluence as a WebDav Server

fields.description:
One of our system admins pointed out to me yesterday that our instance of Tomcat (mainly running Confluence) was using 45% of the CPU,  and ~500Meg of memory.(see screen shots) I think Tomcat had been running almost exactly a week without restart. We have roughly four frequent users of this system and half a dozen casual users at present. Notice too from the screen shots the 241 sessions the Confluence context was hanging on to. This should have been about 4 sessions with our standard timeout settings.

Once I used the Tomcat manager to stop the Confluence context everything dropped to normal with CPU usage down to ~0.05% and sessions dissappearing from the Tomcat manager.

I've noticed too that doing a reload of the Confluence context in Tomcat sometimes causes an 'out of memory' exception meaning Tomcat  is likely not letting go of everything it should.

The unusually high number of sessions noted in the Tomcat manager screenshot seems to at least be one starting point.

Any advice on why CPU and memory usage is so high? Are there any known memory leaks?   

It is possible these are Tomcat issues and not Confluence issues. Are 'high usage' sites (such as Atlassian) finding you have to stop / start the context regularly?
fields.summary: Confluence (or possibly Tomcat) seems to have a memory leak, possibly in relation to hanging on to session

fields.description:
Our enterprise has a large LDAP directory. It would be nice if we could point users at Confluence and they could simply log in, however it appears they first have to be manually created by an administrator, then LDAP is simply used to verify the password at login.  Is this a correct assessment of how things work?

Would it be possible for users to be 'automatically created' the first time they login with a valid LDAP username / password? 

 If this ability doesn't already exist could you give some pointers on how we could go about implementing?
fields.summary: LDAP users can't just log into Confluence, they must first be created.  Is there a way to let them just log in without having to manually create them?

fields.description:
Session event listener threw exception 
java.lang.IllegalStateException: getAttribute: Session already invalidated 
at org.apache.catalina.session.StandardSession.getAttribute(StandardSession.java:953) 
at org.apache.catalina.session.StandardSessionFacade.getAttribute(StandardSessionFacade.java:171) 
at com.atlassian.confluence.user.listeners.UserSessionExpiryListener.sessionDestroyed(UserSessionExpiryListener.java:28) 

Some application servers (such as Tomcat) take a literal interpretation of the servlet spec over, say, a SANE one, and invalidate the HttpSession before passing it to the session listener's sessionDestroyed() method. Because of this, the listener can't actually DO anything with the session, rendering it COMPLETELY USELESS.

We need to find another way to detect when a user has logged out, or at least disable user tracking on those appservers that work this way. Resin and Orion seem fine, Tomcat 4.x is definitely broken, and I suspect Weblogic will behave the Tomcat way.

See also: http://www.caucho.com/support/resin-interest/0207/0332.html
fields.summary: Session already invalidated - UserSessionExpiryListener tries to retrieve attributes from invalid sessions

fields.description:

at org.apache.coyote.tomcat4.CoyoteResponseFacade.sendError(CoyoteResponseFacade.java:324) 
at javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponseWrapper.sendError(HttpServletResponseWrapper.java:162) 

We're doing a response.sendError() after we've already started streaming data to the client. It's too late for the servlet container to back up and try again, so it blows up.

fields.description:
After Confluence runs for a while (hours to days), users notice that none of the email notifications are being sent. When I check, the Mail Queue is empty and the Error Queue is full. I see the following error repeated in the stdout.log many times.

2005-06-15 10:46:01,942 ERROR [atlassian.core.task.ErrorQueuedTaskQueue] com.atlassian.mail.MailException

The log messages do not include a stack trace. I cannot find any other log information regarding this error. When I "Resend error queue" the messages move to the Mail Queue and shortly thereafter they are put back into the Error Queue. When I restart the Confluence service, the Mail Queue successfully flushes itself automatically, but the problem reappears after a while.

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-3407].
  {panel}

Let me start off by saying that you have a very good product here where the focus has been on getting the foundation solid before branching out on too many features.

Here is what i am proposing:
# Ability to download all the attachments on a page via a link.  Now things brings additional complexity because you now have to worry about what version you want to download (which can be specific for each)
** I sugges that we put check boxes in front of each attachment with the ability to select all or individual and a download button (design on the fly here) 
Then the user would get to select a version for each attachment they have selected or stick to the defaults of the most current version.

You could also use this method to delete versions of attachments (i saw this request in another issue)
fields.summary: Enhanced download capabilities for attachments (download all, specific, individual, and what version)

fields.description:
When you deploy Confluence 1.4.1 on Oracle 8.1.7 database and try to change page title you get Oracle error message:
ORA-00933: SQL command not properly ended

The problem is that the following files have hardcoded SQL92 style "INNER JOIN" which is not supported by Oracle 8i:
confluence\WEB-INF\classes\com\atlassian\confluence\core\ContentEntityObject.hbm.xml
confluence\WEB-INF\classes\com\atlassian\confluence\links\persistence\dao\hibernate\HibernateLinkDao$2.class
confluence\WEB-INF\classes\com\atlassian\confluence\links\persistence\dao\hibernate\HibernateLinkDao$3.class
confluence\WEB-INF\classes\com\atlassian\confluence\pages\persistence\dao\hibernate\HibernatePageDao$2.class

I rewrote these SQL statements in these files without INNER JOIN syntax and after that everything works fine.
Modified files are included in attachment.

It would be good not to use hardcoded INNER JOIN statements as it limits functionality of Confluence on older database versions. All dynamically created SQLs that are generated by Hibarnate are OK for Oracle 8i.
fields.summary: Errors deploying Confluence on Oracle 8i - INNER JOIN hardcoded in Confluence classes

fields.description: There is bug in space.vmd decorator fragment: --- #if ($blog.comments.size() > 0) $blog.comments.size() comment#if($blog.comments.size() > 1)s#end #else 0 comments #end --- If blog title contains national (non-ascii) character then $generalUtil.getPageUrl($blog) returns something like /pages/viewpage.action?pageId=xxx As a result the final URL is /pages/viewpage.action?pageId=xxx?showComments=true#comments which gives server exception when clicked (as it contains two ? in URL, in this case second ? should be replaced with &) The following workaround was made to avoid this issue: --- #if ($generalUtil.getPageUrl($blog).indexOf("?") < 0) #set( $sep = "?" ) #else #set( $sep = "&" ) #end #if ($blog.comments.size() > 0) $blog.comments.size() comment#if($blog.comments.size() > 1)s#end #else 0 comments #end ---
fields.summary: Invalid formatting in space.vmd of URL links to blog comments in News Items page if non-ascii characters present in blog title

  {panel}

(Couldn't see any mention of this anywhere else; sorry if it's a repeated post)

The dynamictasklist macro, while handy, has some problems:

* There's no option to rename/edit a task, so if you make a mistake you have to delete the task and re-enter it from scratch.

* Drag-and-drop to re-order the task list doesn't work - the item moves as you would expect when you drag it, but if you reload the page, it usually jumps back to its original position.

* Generation of task lists is very slow. I've added a task list for 12 different users, and then used {include} to summarise everyone's tasks, and even when all the task lists are empty it takes about 30 seconds to build and display the page.
fields.summary: dynamictasklist improvements

fields.description:
If the 'attach files to profile' permission is disabled, no one should be able to do it. Currently, administrators can ignore the permission for their own profile but not others.

If I disable all 'attach file to profile' permissions then my admin.s  can still attach files to their profiles. This isn't the case of administrator privileges overriding all security checks as the admin.s cannot attach files to the profiles of others. 

If admin.s can override the perm. then they should be allowed to attach files to all profiles!  Right now it's inconsistent.
fields.summary: Attach files to profile permission is inconsistent for administrators

Everything works properly when I move the plugin jar from ${confluence.home}plugins into .../WEB-INF/lib.

I suspect that the /download/* servlet is not looking at the plugin directory when serving downloadable plugin resources.

I have two spaces...and am unsure what other information would help to debug this.  I find it a little strange that the global template needs a space name.

More information...I have changed the global page layout slightly, but all I did was move things around.  I also changed some space-page layouts, but wouldn't expect them to come into the picture here.

Have a nice day.
fields.summary: Creating global template throws null pointer exception in getSpaceName

fields.description: A link to the file system like [file://D:\Temp\logo.gif] is rendered as href="file://D:Templogo.gif". This worked fine with 1.3.x but not with 1.4.1.
fields.summary: [file://  links break with \

fields.description:
The following snippet {color:red} h1. foo {color} renders as


h1. foo

I.e. the heading is not rendered as a heading...
fields.summary: headings not rendered if inside {color} macro

fields.description: We have a user macro defined as follows: #if ($body) $body #else $param0 #end The macro is used to link to an arbitrary page / file in another path on the same server. It can either be used as {file:foo} or {file:foo}bar{file}. The {file:foo} usage worked fine in Confluence 1.3.x as the #if ($body) test evaluated to false. In Confluence 1.4.1, however, this test seems to evaluate to true, even though the macro was not passed a body. I am not sure if this is a bug or not. I am sure we can work around this by comparing $body to the empty string. I just noticed that Confluence had changed here.
fields.summary: $body always defined for user macros

fields.description:
- Enable CamelCase
- Create a template with a variable named in CamelCase or all UPPERCASE
- observe that the preview page as well as the "fill in variables" page when creating a new page from a template render the variable in question with invalid HTML
- If you fill in text in the textbox and submit, the variable is not substituted.
fields.summary: CamelCase interferes with page template variables

fields.description:
Livesearch in general appears to have some wacky rendering. In this case, I noticed it while using the panel macro.

See this test page for an example:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/5dwB

Not only does the livesearch macro "push away" from the margin (the second set of bold words are not aligned with the first), but the consecutive panels are actually *nested* now! Whoa.
fields.summary: Livesearch macro rendering (breaks panels for one)
